comments.author: Melissa
comments.content: This looks delicious! I don't like regular lasagna with all the tomato sauce, so this sounds great!

comments.author: Tracy
comments.content: If you're okay with a wetter lasagna, even regular noodles can be no-boil, provided you cook the 'gna long enough.  Mmm, winter comfort food.  In other news, I recently impressed the heck out of my out-laws with your five-minute Indian-style cabbage recipe.  Thanks again — that one's a keeper for sure.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
I was wondering whether regular noodles can be used in a no-boil fashion.
Thanks for letting me know without having to risk the experiment myself :).
And I'm delighted you liked the cabbage!

comments.author: Howard.H
comments.content:
Hi there:
The article is very interesting! Do you mind I share it on my web project? I am current developing a web site focusing on how-2's. Here's the intro video:
http://blip.tv/file/1019119
BTW, I am the core developer of this website. It's a small website still, but hoping you can help me by agreeing sharing this article. If you would like give me any opinion, plz feel free to email me at: ccool2486@gmail.com

comments.author: Joie de vivre
comments.content: Looks yummy!  I'm not a fan of the crispy cheese top though preferring mine to be gooey.  Yours may change my mind though!

comments.author: apricotnelli
comments.content: This looks great.  I make something similar with radicchio which I grow in my garden and it is to die for.. if you like the bitter taste.  I mix the radicchio with the ricotta and finish with bechamel. Sometimes I finish with gorgonzola...

comments.author: Rebecca
comments.content: This recipe rocked the house for a girls' night in...plus I discovered that cauliflower can taste good. I've since sauteed it to spruce up spaghetti sauce.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN">
@rebecca - I'm glad you liked the lasagna! Now that you are a cauliflower lover, try oven roasting it - olive oil, salt, 450 until getting some nice dark brown spots. The caramelization is killer.

comments.author: Caley
comments.content: Real happy to have found your blog. Great creativity with vegetarian cooking. Lasagna in the oven as I write this. Can't wait to try!

comments.author: Kim
comments.content: This Italian girl is looking for veggie version and I'm going to give this one a try.  It sounds great--the nutmeg and lemon zest sounds like a really nice touch.  Can't wait to try it!!!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Thanks Kim! Hope you like it. I've got another version too, with portobellos and summer squash: https://herbivoracious.com//2009/09/summer-squas-and-portobello-vegetarian-lasagna-recipe.html

comments.author: Lisa
comments.content:
Michael,

Do you think broccoli could be substituted for the cauliflower?

Lisa

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Yes, I think that would be just fine. Be sure and cut it up small so it doesn't interfere with the texture.

comments.author: dan
comments.content: I'm making this for tonight for the second time in a week. Last Friday, it fed 5 hungry skiers and they loved it. Substituted chard for the spinach since that's what I had in the house. I also use my homemade meatless pasta sauce in place of plain tomato sauce. It adds a whole dimension of garlic, anise, wine, and heirloom tomatoes canned at the height of the season last year.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Glad you like the recipe! There is nothing like a hearty meal after a day of skiing. Your homemade pasta sauce sounds great - the anise is a smart addition, it boost the umami when cooked with onions. (A very interesting reaction).

comments.author: Cate
comments.content: Just made this (added some zucchini) and it is FANTASTIC! Thanks so much for another great recipe (your blog is one of my favorites)

comments.author: Megan Keogh
comments.content:
Michael, houseful of relatives next week - do you think it would be OK for me to make and then freeze before cooking. I'm really looking forward to trying this recipe!

Megan

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Hey Megan - well, I've never tried freezing this, either before or after baking so I have no direct experience to go on, but this web page appears to have some useful tips: http://www.pasta-recipes-made-easy.com/freezing-lasagna.html - if you try it, please let me know how it turns out. Thanks, Michael

comments.author: Dianna Gillespie
comments.content:
Hi Michael,

I'm clearly late to the party on reading and commenting. Just wanted to say that I've made a lasagna with kale (stems removed) and red sauce without previously cooking either the noodles or the kale, and it turned out pretty good. 
Thank you for keeping this blog updated so regularly with beautiful food.

comments.author: Virginia
comments.content: I JUST made this - it is my very first lasagna I've ever made! (I'm new to cooking). It is so outstanding!! Thank you for posting it! I will use this recipe for the rest of my life. :) Thank you.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Hey Virginia - congrats on your first lasagna, and I'm glad you liked it! By the way, if you feel like branching out, you might want to try this one too: https://herbivoracious.com/2009/09/summer-squas-and-portobello-vegetarian-lasagna-recipe.html

comments.author: Laura Johnson
comments.content: This rocked the casbah.

comments.author: Maya
comments.content: About how much spinach does this recipe call for (by weight)? In the markets nearby, I can only find spinach in pre-packed containers.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
Hi Maya -

I apologize, I wrote that recipe quite awhile ago and the way I've specified the measurement certainly isn't easy to translate! I'd guesstimate about 12 ounces.

comments.author: Maya
comments.content:
Thanks! 
BTW I just bought your cookbook and the recipes look great! I can't wait to try out those recipes!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Thanks for buying it, Maya, and I hope you enjoy it! Keep me posted as to what you make. A nice place to stay in touch is the Herbivoracious facebook page: http://www.facebook.com/herbivoracious

comments.author: Jayne
comments.content: This looks great. I don't care for eggs, I will try it out without and see what happens...

comments.author: Scarfy
comments.content: Although I eat meat, I've never been a fan of meat lasagna. This is by far the tastiest vegetarian lasagna I've ever tasted!! The lemon zest takes it over the top! I added mushrooms  and used boiled pasta, but followed the recipe otherwise. Definitely adding this one to my repertoire! Thank you!!

comments.author: Nicole
comments.content: This recipe is phenomenal! The second time I made it I used more spinach than called for in the recipe and also added 1 diced squash and 1 zucchini to the cauliflower (which I chopped more finely than the first time and it was better). I love that I can add additional veggies and get more nutritional value without taking away from the amazing-ness of the recipe.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Sounds like great customization!

comments.author: Sam James
comments.content: Great tip about the veggies, amazing site, looks delicious
